description.narrative: Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The International Development Law Organisation (IDLO) has submitted a proposal of 30 MSEK to support a project aiming to increase access to justice for the Kenyan citizens, increase transparency and accountability on national and county levels, in line with the 2010 Constitution of Kenya. The contribution will support key institutions within the justice sector to implement their Strategic Plan as well as the blueprint " Sustaining Judiciary Transformation" (SJT). The project will also support the National Council on Administration of Justice (NCAJ), including actors within the criminal justic chain, with the ongoing implementation of reforms. Legal aid is another substantial component in the project, and the implementation of the 2016 Legal Aid Act aiming to secure legal aid to vulnerable people, will receive support. The project will also support CSOs and Constitutional Commissions in terms of transparency and accountability, including public complaints handling mechanisms. Important actors such as the Office of the Auditor General; Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission, the OAG/DOJ, the Council of Governors, the National Treasury and the Parliamentary Budget Office will be supported in developing of policies and compliance.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 The International Development Law Organisation (IDLO) har inkommit med en ansökan om 30 MSEK för att stödja ett projekt med syfte att öka de kenyanska medborgarnas tillgång till rättssystemet/rättvisa, öka transparens och ansvarsutkrävande på både nationell och länsnivå, enligt Kenyas grundlag från 2010. Insatsen kommer att stödja nyckelinstitutioner inom rättsväsendet för att genomföra den strategiska planen och styrdokumentet "Sustaining Judiciary Transformation" (SJT). Projektet kommer även att stödja det 'nationella rådet för rättsskipning' (National Council on Administration of Justice, NCAJ), där bl.a. aktörer inom straffrätten ingår, i dess reformer mot större öppenhet och ansvarsutkrävande från medborgarna. Rättshjälp (legal aid) är en annan viktig komponent i projektet som kommer stödja implementeringen av den lag från 2016 som ska säkra att även utsatta människor får tillgång till rättshjälp. Projektet kommer även att arbeta med civilsamhällesorganisationer och grundlagskommissioner vad gäller öppenhet och ansvarsutkrävande, inklusive mekanismer för allmänheten att framföra klagomål mot nationella och lokala myndigheter. Viktiga aktörer som den kenyanska riksrevisionen, antikorruptionskommissionen, justitiedepartementet, guvernörsrådet (Council of Governors), finansdepartementet och parlamentets budgetkontor kommer att stödjas i arbetet med att ta fram policydokument och efterlevnad

description.narrative: In the last six months, IDLO focused on strengthening institutional capacity of the Judiciary, the National Council on Administration of Justice (NCAJ) and other relevant justice sector actors, improve access to justice through reduction of case backlog; enhanced quality of legal frameworks for access to justice, improved linkages between formal and informal justice systems; and improved coordination of justice actors under the NCAJ leadership. The follwoing are some of the results that have been realised: 1. Enhanced access to justice through reduced case backlog in the Court of Appeal: IDLO supported reduction of the backlog in the Court of Appeal (COA) through support to service weeks and circuit visits to court stations where the COA does not ordinarily sit. The planned service week in March for the Kisumu Law courts was disrupted by theGovernment directive for nationwide lockdown. This did not affect the matters that had been set for hearing, as all the 62 matters scheduled for hearing were heard and determined through video-conferencing. From April 2020, COA hearings were virtual. As of June 2020, 219 appeal cases have been heard and determined and 213 rulings/ judgements delivered. Virtual hearings have ensured reduction of appeal case backlog and continuity of administration of justice during the pandemic. 2. Enhanced access to information on ongoing automation of judicial processes: Due to the effects of COVID-19 and the need to address emerging justice needs, IDLO supported the Judiciary’s Directorate of Public Affairs and Communications (DPAC) to run media public announcements and television infomercials in June 2020. The infomercials provided information to citizens on how to access the courts virtually for E-filing of cases, E-payment of court fees, virtual hearing of matters and delivery of rulings and judgments. This dissemination of information has also helped to subvert the misinformation on how the courts were operating during the pandemic, especially amongst litigants. 3. Civil Procedure (Amendment) Rules gazetted for implementation: IDLO supported development of the Civil Procedure (Amendment) Rules in 2019, through a Legislative Drafter in the Rules Committee to support the draftingand validation of pending rules. However, the finalised Rules had been pending review and gazettement by the Office of the Attorney General (OAG). On 22 February 2020, the Civil Procedure (Amendment) Rules were finally gazetted for implementation. The Rules simplify processes in the handling of civil matters and provide clarity on provisions of the Civil Procedure Act that have overtime been interpreted differently by the different courts. Full implementation ofthe Rules alongside the Act will accelerate adjudication of civil matters and contribute to reduction of case backlog in the courts currently handling civil cases. 4. Guidelines for implementation of the Access to Information Act developed and adopted: IDLO partnered with the Commission on Administration of Justice (CAJ) to develop Guidelines to aid implementation of Access to Information Act, 2016. This was through stakeholder consultations with the CAJ, various Government officesincluding the Office of the Attorney General (OAG), the Kenya Law Reform Commission (KLRC), Ministry of Information, Kenya National Registration Bureau of Statistics, and CSOs. 5. Framework for the implementation of the Legal Audit Report developed: IDLO supported KLRC and the Council of Governors (COG) to develop the Implementation Framework for the Legal Audit Report, as a road map for implementation of County level policy, legislative and administrative reforms with a view to strengthening devolution in Kenya. The Framework developed to operationalise the findings of the Legal Audit of the National and County policies and laws developed in 2019.
